awd_abstract_narration:
This RUI award funds the research activities of Professor Matthew Mewes at California Polytechnic State University.

Lorentz invariance is thought to be an exact symmetry of nature. It is the basis of special relativity and implies that the laws of physics are the same for all observers.  However, attempts to unify our two most fundamental descriptions of nature, the Standard Model of particle physics and general relativity, into a single all-encompassing theory suggest that Lorentz invariance might be broken slightly.  The research of Professor Mewes focuses on violations of Lorentz invariance, with the goal of extending the theoretical description of Lorentz-invariance violations and identifying experimental signatures in an effort to aid the search for new physics. This research advances the national interest by promoting science in one of its most fundamental directions:  the discovery and understanding of new physical laws.  Parts of this work will be accessible to undergraduates and will provide research opportunities for physics majors at Cal Poly, a primarily undergraduate institution.  Students involved in this research will also gain valuable exposure to theoretical physics.

In more technical terms, this project seeks to fill several major gaps in the theoretical framework known as the Standard-Model-Extension (SME). The SME provides a general description of Lorentz violation in any system. The generality of this approach implies that the full SME contains an infinite number of violations. To keep the problem tractable, early studies focused on the minimal SME, which restricts attention to operators of renormalizable mass dimension.  However, there are reasons to suspect that nonrenormalizable violations may dominate. This project will extend our understanding of Lorentz-invariance violations by completing the extension for linearized gravity and by exploring various consequences in that sector. It also seeks to fill gaps in the Lorentz-violating extension of quantum electrodynamics by classifying violations in fermion-photon interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All of modern physics is, in principle, contained in two theories that describe nature at two different distance scales. The first is the Standard Model of particle physics, which is relevant at very small scales and characterizes all the subatomic particles and three of the fundamental forces: the electromagnetic, weak and strong forces. The other theory is Einstein's General Relativity, which explains the forth force, gravity, and works on large scales. Physicists expect that these two theories stem from a single theory that encompasses all matter and forces, but we have yet to discover this ultimate description of nature. This unifying theory remains a mystery due largely to the extreme energies that would be required to test it directly, putting it out of reach of current technology. Violations of Lorentz invariance, if discovered, could provide valuable less-direct evidence of this theory.

Lorentz invariance is the mathematical principle behind Einstein's Special Relativity, the theory that says physics is independent of the frame of reference of the observer. Lorentz invariance is a feature of both the Standard Model and General Relativity. However, several mechanisms exist that allow Lorentz invariance to be broken slightly in more fundamental theories. If found, this breaking, called Lorentz violation, could provide the hints physicists need to piece together a unified picture of nature.

The PI's theoretical research focuses on Lorentz violation in the Standard Model and General Relativity. The work supported by this award has extended our theoretical understanding of potential Lorentz violations in gravity and will aid in the search for Lorentz violation in gravitational waves that are produced by the collisions of black holes. Another part of the research explored new techniques for calculating the effects of Lorentz violation in laboratory-based experiments designed to test Newtonian gravity on small distance scales. The PI also studied methods of testing Lorentz invariance using the flash of light produced during the big bang and the effects of violations in ordinary macroscopic matter. This award also provided support for three undergraduate research projects, giving students valuable exposure to theoretical physics.
